Homework (due 0207)

Complete these for Wednesday, February 7. Where appropriate, show work that justifies your answers for full credit.

  1. For the equation \(x^2+y^2=1\), confirm that \((0,1)\) is a point on the graph and that \((1,1)\) is not.

    To see that \((0,1)\) is a point on the graph, we substitute \(0\) for \(x\) and \(1\) for \(y\) and get \((0)^2+(1)^2 = 1,\) which is true. Since \((0,1)\) satisfies the equation, it is a point on the graph.

    To see that \((1,1)\) is not a point on the graph, we substitute \(1\) for \(x\) and \(1\) for \(y\) and get \((1)^2+(1)^2 = 1,\) which is false. Since \((1,1)\) does not satisfy the equation, it is not a point on the graph.

  2. Find three points that are on the graph of \(\sqrt{x^2+1}=3y-2\) and three points that are not.

    The points \(\left(0,1\right)\), \(\left(\sqrt{3},\frac{4}{3}\right)\), and \(\left(-\sqrt{3},\frac{4}{3}\right)\) are on the graph, among others.

    The points \((0,0)\), \((0,2)\), and \((1,0)\) are not on the graph, among others.

  3. Find all \(x\)-intercepts and \(y\)-intercepts of the graphs of the following equations. Be sure to indicate which answers are \(x\)-intercepts and which are \(y\)-intercepts, and express all answers as points (both coordinates).

    1. \(\frac{x}{2}+\frac{y}{3}=1\): When \(y=0\), we get \(\frac{x}{2}=1\), and so \(x=2.\) Thus \((2,0)\) is the only \(x\)-intercept. When \(x=0\), we get \(\frac{y}{3}=1\), and so \(y=3.\) Thus \((0,3)\) is the only \(y\)-intercept.
    2. \(y=1-x^2\): When \(y=0\), we get \(0=1-x^2\), and so \(x=\pm 1.\) Thus \((1,0)\) and \((-1,0)\) are the only \(x\)-intercepts. When \(x=0\), we get \(y=1.\) Thus \((0,1)\) is the only \(y\)-intercept.
    3. \(\frac{x-1}{x+1}=y+2\): When \(y=0\), we get \(\frac{x-1}{x+1}=2\), and so \(x-1=2(x+1).\) Then \(x-1=2x+2.\) Then \(x=-3.\) Thus \((-3,0)\) is the only \(x\)-intercept. When \(x=0\), we get \(\frac{-1}{1}=y+2\), and so \(y=-3\). Thus \((0,-3)\) is the only \(y\)-intercept.
    4. \((x-3)^2+(y-2)^2=16\): When \(y=0\), we get \((x-3)^2+4=16.\) Then \((x-3)^2=12.\) Then \(x=3\pm\sqrt{12}.\) Thus \((3+\sqrt{12},0)\) and \((3-\sqrt{12},0)\) are the only \(x\)-intercepts. When \(x=0\), we get \(9+(y-2)^2=16.\) Thus \((y-2)^2=7\). Thus \(y=2\pm\sqrt{7}.\) Thus \((0,2+\sqrt{7})\) and \((0,2-\sqrt{7})\) are the only \(y\)-intercepts.
    5. \(y=\frac{1}{x}+1\): When \(y=0\), we get \(0=\frac{1}{x}+1\), and so \(x=-1.\) Thus \((-1,0)\) is the only \(x\)-intercept. When \(x=0\), the right hand side is undefined. Thus this graph has no \(y\)-intercepts.

  4. Determine the domain of each of the following functions.

    1. \(f(x)=x^2-3x+1\): the domain is \((-\infty,\infty).\)
    2. \(f(x)=\frac{1}{x^2-1}\): the domain is all real numbers except those that make \(x^2-1\) equal to zero. Thus the domain is \((-\infty,-1)\cup(-1,1)\cup(1,\infty).\)
    3. \(f(x)=\sqrt{2x-1}\): the domain is all real numbers except those that make \(2x-1\) negative. So \(2x-1\) must be zero or positive. Thus \(2x-1\geq 0\). Thus \(x\geq \frac{1}{2}\). Thus the domain is \(\left[\frac{1}{2},\infty\right).\)
    4. \(f(x)=\frac{x-2}{\sqrt{3x-5}}\): the domain is all real numbers except those that cause us to divide by zero or to take the square root of a negative. When \(x=\frac{5}{3}\), the denominator is zero. When \(3x-5\lt 0\), or \(x\lt\frac{5}{3}\), the root is undefined. Thus the domain is \(\left(\frac{5}{3},\infty\right).\)

  5. Use Desmos or a graphing calculator to determine the range of the functions from Question 4.

    1. \(f(x)=x^2-3x+1\): the range is \((-\infty,\infty).\)
    2. \(f(x)=\frac{1}{x^2-1}\): the range is \((-\infty,-1]\cup(0,\infty).\)
    3. \(f(x)=\sqrt{2x-1}\): the range is \([0,\infty).\)
    4. \(f(x)=\frac{x-2}{\sqrt{3x-5}}\): the range is \((-\infty,\infty).\)
